meta.notes: 100 neurology board-style MCQs with balanced correct choices; 20% easy, 30% moderate, 50% hard.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old presents with slowly progressive proximal muscle weakness. EMG shows small, short-duration, polyphasic MUAPs with early recruitment. Most consistent diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Myopathies cause small, short-duration, polyphasic MUAPs with early recruitment. Motor neuron disease shows large, long-duration units. Neuromuscular junction disorders show decrement. Neuropathies show reduced recruitment.

questions.stem: Which nerve is most commonly studied for sensory conduction in suspected carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.explanation: Median sensory conduction across the wrist is most sensitive for CTS. Radial and ulnar help in comparison. Peroneal is lower limb.

questions.stem: Which finding on repetitive nerve stimulation at 2â€“3 Hz suggests myasthenia gravis?
questions.explanation: Myasthenia gravis shows >10% decrement at low-frequency stimulation. Increment is seen in Lambert-Eaton. Myotonic discharges are EMG, not RNS.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old man has distal weakness and wasting with fasciculations. EMG shows fibrillation potentials and large amplitude MUAPs. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: ALS shows denervation (fibs, fascics) and reinnervation (large MUAPs). Polymyositis shows small units. Lambert-Eaton shows increment, botulism shows NMJ failure.

questions.stem: Which neuropathy typically shows markedly slowed conduction velocity (<30 m/s) with uniform slowing?
questions.explanation: Demyelination causes slowed velocities and prolonged latencies. Axonal neuropathy has low amplitudes. NMJ and MND show normal velocities.

questions.stem: Conduction block on NCS is defined as: (case 6)
options: >50% amplitude drop across a segment with normal distal response
questions.explanation: Conduction block is significant amplitude drop across segment with preserved distal response.

questions.stem: Which EMG finding indicates active denervation? (case 7)
options: Fibrillation potentials and positive sharp waves
questions.explanation: Active denervation shows fibrillations and positive sharp waves. Large MUAPs suggest reinnervation. Decrement indicates NMJ defect.

questions.stem: In Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, high-frequency stimulation shows? (case 8)
questions.explanation: LEMS shows post-exercise or high-frequency incremental response.

options: >50% amplitude drop across a segment with normal distal response
questions.explanation: Conduction block is significant amplitude drop across segment with preserved distal response.
